Subject Matter: Meetings with members of the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs & Trade (JCFAT)
Intended Results: Regular measurement and evaluation of Ireland's delivery of its commitments to people with disabilities as stated in its Overseas Aid Development Policy and as ratified in the Sustainable Development Goals.
Lobbying Activities:
18th September - meeting with some members of JCFAT to discuss the SDGs and Ireland's commitments to people with disabilities in its Overseas Development Aid Policy. Present: Maureen O'Sullivan TD and personal assistants of Olivia Mitchell TD and Senator Ruairi Quinn TD. Meeting with Sarah O'Toole CEO CBM Ireland, Dr Mary Keogh Board Member CBM Ireland and Dave McComiskey President CBM International
2nd December - formal presentation to JCFAT by Sarah O'Toole CEO CBM Ireland, Dr Mary Keogh Board Member CBM Ireland and Lars Bosselmann Director of Advocacy CBM International|Meeting|2-5

Specific Details: Impact of Irish Tax policies towards multinationals on developing countries
DPOs Lobbied: Maureen O'Sullivan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Olivia Mitchell|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Bernard Durkan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Seán Crowe|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Jim Walsh|Senator|Seanad::Anthony Lawlor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Impact of Irish Tax policies towards multinationals on developing countries
Intended Results: Highlight awareness of two DDCI reports, Corporate Tax Secrecy and the State: the Apple case in Ireland” in which DDCI called for a Public Accounts Committee review of Revenue's system of secret tax rulings, and a pan-European civil society report, 'Fifty Shades of Tax Dodging - the EU's role in supporting an unjust global tax system'

Specific Details: Request to the Oireachtas Committees on Health and Agriculture to review the validity of proposed legislation amending Misuse of Drugs Act(s)
DPOs Lobbied: Jackie Cahill|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Seán Crowe|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Request to the Oireachtas Committees on Health and Agriculture to review the validity of proposed legislation amending Misuse of Drugs Act(s)
Intended Results: To stay the progress of proposed legislation pending clarification of its apparent and substantial conflict with EU law, EU Court of Justice rulings and clarifications of the Irish High Court::Clarification of the validity of the criminal prosecution of Irish hemp operators for failing to possess Ministerial licences when no such licences existed and no legal mechanism allowing for the provision of such licences existed within the State.::Acknowledgement that EU CMO regulations which are directly applicable to Ireland have already established the legal THC content in the EU hemp crop.::Clarification of the legal basis for the regulation of the legal EU hemp crop as a controlled drug by the Irish Revenue Commissioners.::Restoration of the annual incomes of Irish hemp farmers.::Clarification of the legality of the refusal to issue cultivation licences to Irish hemp farmers in 2022::Acknowledgement of the clarifications provided by the EU Commission regarding appropriate regulation of the agricultural hemp crop and derived products.::Clarification of the legality of extraordinary interpretation(s) and application(s) of EU Novel Food law within the hemp sector in Ireland.::Acknowledgement of the fact that CBD can only be made using the flowers and leaves of the hemp plant as clarified by the EU Court of Justice ruling in case C-663/18::A full investigation into the legality of the regulation of the EU agricultural hemp crop and derived products as narcotic drugs by Irish authorities since 2018 and its impact on the lives, livelihoods, families and reputations of Irish hemp farmers and operators.
Lobbying Activities: A letter was sent to both Oireachtas Committees (Health and Agriculture) via their respective Clerks/Secretariats.|Letter|2-5
